sn12.65:1.2.pli: “Pubbe me, bhikkhave, sambodhā anabhisambuddhassa bodhisattasseva sato etadahosi:
sn12.65:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:
sn12.65:1.2.comm: This process describes the Buddha’s reflection before his awakening. It is of particular interest because it seems to depict the precise moment when his insight broke away from that of his Upaniṣadic teachers. Bhikkhu Bodhi notes: “It it possible the Bodhisatta had been seeking a self of the Upaniṣadic type, a self-subsistent subject consisting of pure consciousness that requires nothing but itself in order to exist. His discovery that consciousness is invariably dependent on name-and-form would have disclosed to him the futility of such a quest and thereby shown that even consciousness, the subtlest basis for the sense of self (see SN 12.61), is conditioned and thus marked by impermanence, suffering, and selflessness.”

sn12.65:1.3.pli: ‘kicchā vatāyaṃ loko āpanno jāyati ca jīyati ca mīyati ca cavati ca upapajjati ca.
sn12.65:1.3.eng: ‘Alas, this world has fallen into trouble. It’s born, grows old, dies, passes away, and is reborn,

sn12.65:1.4.pli: Atha ca panimassa dukkhassa nissaraṇaṃ nappajānāti jarāmaraṇassa.
sn12.65:1.4.eng: yet it doesn’t understand how to escape from this suffering, from old age and death.

sn12.65:1.5.pli: Kudāssu nāma imassa dukkhassa nissaraṇaṃ paññāyissati jarāmaraṇassā’ti?
sn12.65:1.5.eng: Oh, when will an escape be found from this suffering, from old age and death?’

sn12.65:1.7.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho sati jarāmaraṇaṃ hoti, kiṃpaccayā jarāmaraṇan’ti?
sn12.65:1.7.eng: ‘When what exists is there old age and death? What is a requirement for old age and death?’

sn12.65:1.8.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
sn12.65:1.8.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, I penetrated with wisdom:

sn12.65:1.9.pli: ‘jātiyā kho sati jarāmaraṇaṃ hoti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇan’ti.
sn12.65:1.9.eng: ‘When rebirth exists there’s old age and death. Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death.’

sn12.65:2.10.eng: What is a requirement for name and form?’

sn12.65:2.11.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
sn12.65:2.11.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, I penetrated with wisdom:

sn12.65:2.12.pli: ‘viññāṇe kho sati nāmarūpaṃ hoti, viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpan’ti.
sn12.65:2.12.eng: ‘When consciousness exists there are name and form. Consciousness is a requirement for name and form.’
sn12.65:2.12.comm: This analysis agrees with Yājñavalkya, who says that the manifold appearances in the world arise from consciousness (etebhyo bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.12).

sn12.65:2.14.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho sati viññāṇaṃ hoti, kiṃpaccayā viññāṇan’ti?
sn12.65:2.14.eng: ‘When what exists is there consciousness? What is a requirement for consciousness?’

sn12.65:2.15.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
sn12.65:2.15.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, I penetrated with wisdom:

sn12.65:2.16.pli: ‘nāmarūpe kho sati viññāṇaṃ hoti, nāmarūpapaccayā viññāṇan’ti.
sn12.65:2.16.eng: ‘When name and form exist there’s consciousness. Name and form are requirements for consciousness.’
sn12.65:2.16.comm: Here the Buddha contradicts Yājñavalkya’s view that individuated awareness (saññā) returns into “this great reality, infinite, unbounded, a sheer mass of consciousness” (idaṁ mahadbhūtam anantam apāraṁ vijñānaghana eva, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.12). Consciousness (viññāṇa) is not a fundamental reality (mahadbhūta) underlying multiplicity, but rather a conditioned process that exists only together with name and form.

sn12.65:3.2.pli: paccudāvattati kho idaṃ viññāṇaṃ nāmarūpamhā na paraṃ gacchati.
sn12.65:3.2.eng: This consciousness turns back from name and form, and doesn’t go beyond that.
sn12.65:3.2.comm: The same idea is found at DN 14:2.19.2, where it also describes the reflective process of a Bodhisatta. The mutual conditioning of consciousness with name and form is then further detailed at DN 15:21.1 and SN 12.67. It seems that this distinctive presentation was the original form for describing a Bodhisatta’s thought process. It was subsequently applied to the full set of twelve links (SN 12.4).

sn12.65:3.3.pli: Ettāvatā jāyetha vā jīyetha vā mīyetha vā cavetha vā upapajjetha vā, yadidaṃ nāmarūpapaccayā viññāṇaṃ;
sn12.65:3.3.eng: This is the extent to which one may be reborn, grow old, die, pass away, or reappear. That is: name and form are requirements for consciousness.

sn12.65:3.4.eng: Consciousness is a requirement for name and form.

sn12.65:3.5.eng: Name and form are requirements for the six sense fields.

sn12.65:3.6.eng: The six sense fields are requirements for contact. …

sn12.65:3.7.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.65:3.8.pli: ‘Samudayo, samudayo’ti kho me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi ñāṇaṃ udapādi paññā udapādi vijjā udapādi āloko udapādi.
sn12.65:3.8.eng: ‘Origination, origination.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.

sn12.65:4.2.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho asati, jarāmaraṇaṃ na hoti;
sn12.65:4.2.eng: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no old age and death?

sn12.65:4.3.eng: When what ceases do old age and death cease?’

sn12.65:4.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
sn12.65:4.4.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, I penetrated with wisdom:

sn12.65:4.5.eng: ‘When rebirth doesn’t exist there is no old age and death.

sn12.65:4.6.eng: When rebirth ceases old age and death cease.’

sn12.65:4.8.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho asati jāti na hoti …pe…
sn12.65:4.8.eng: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no rebirth …

sn12.65:4.16.eng: When what ceases do name and form cease?’

sn12.65:4.17.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
sn12.65:4.17.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, I penetrated with wisdom:

sn12.65:4.18.eng: ‘When consciousness doesn’t exist there is no name and form.

sn12.65:4.19.eng: When consciousness ceases name and form cease.’

sn12.65:5.2.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho asati viññāṇaṃ na hoti;
sn12.65:5.2.eng: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no consciousness?

sn12.65:5.3.eng: When what ceases does consciousness cease?’

sn12.65:5.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
sn12.65:5.4.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, I penetrated with wisdom:

sn12.65:5.5.eng: ‘When name and form don’t exist, there is no consciousness.

sn12.65:5.6.eng: When name and form cease, consciousness ceases.’

sn12.65:6.2.pli: adhigato kho myāyaṃ maggo bodhāya yadidaṃ—
sn12.65:6.2.eng: I have discovered the path to awakening. That is:
sn12.65:6.2.comm: This phrase is found only here and DN 14:2.21.2.

sn12.65:6.3.eng: When name and form cease, consciousness ceases.

sn12.65:6.4.eng: When consciousness ceases, name and form cease.

sn12.65:6.5.eng: When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease.

sn12.65:6.6.eng: When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases. …

sn12.65:6.7.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn12.65:6.8.pli: ‘Nirodho, nirodho’ti kho me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi ñāṇaṃ udapādi paññā udapādi vijjā udapādi āloko udapādi.
sn12.65:6.8.eng: ‘Cessation, cessation.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.

sn12.65:7.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso araññe pavane caramāno passeyya purāṇaṃ maggaṃ purāṇañjasaṃ pubbakehi manussehi anuyātaṃ.
sn12.65:7.1.eng: Suppose a person was walking through a forest. They’d see an ancient path, an ancient route traveled by humans in the past.
sn12.65:7.1.comm: Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.8 quotes an ancient verse to the effect: “I have reached the subtle, extensive, ancient road; it has been realized by me”. | Añjasa is elsewhere in Pali used only in poetry (eg, Thag 1.35:1.3) or by brahmins (DN 13:4.2). It is an old Vedic term for the “direct route” to the right place as advised by Pūṣan (Rig Veda 6.54.1). In the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, the new and full moon offerings are made “directly and expressly” to Indra and Agni (2.4.17); one goes “directly to the truth” after a dispute over supremacy among the gods is resolved (3.4.2.14); the horse knows the “direct” way to heaven that humans do not, like one who knows the country (13.2.3–2); and Yājñavalkya explains how to go “directly” to complete the sacrifice (13.5.3.5). One beholds “directly” that the self is god (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.15).

sn12.65:7.3.pli: Tamanugacchanto passeyya purāṇaṃ nagaraṃ purāṇaṃ rājadhāniṃ pubbakehi manussehi ajjhāvuṭṭhaṃ ārāmasampannaṃ vanasampannaṃ pokkharaṇīsampannaṃ uddhāpavantaṃ ramaṇīyaṃ.
sn12.65:7.3.eng: they’d see an ancient city, an ancient capital, inhabited by humans in the past. It was lovely, complete with parks, groves, lotus ponds, and embankments.
sn12.65:7.3.comm: The idea of such “lost cities” decaying in the jungle is probably sparked by the archaeological remains of the Indus Valley Civilization, whose extensive cities would have been over a thousand years old in the Buddha’s day. One major site, Rakhigarhi, is a few day’s walk from Kammāsadamma, where the Buddha taught several times. He could easily have seen it himself or else heard about it.

sn12.65:7.4.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, puriso rañño vā rājamahāmattassa vā āroceyya:
sn12.65:7.4.eng: Then that person would inform a king or their chief minister:

sn12.65:7.5.pli: ‘yagghe, bhante, jāneyyāsi—ahaṃ addasaṃ araññe pavane caramāno purāṇaṃ maggaṃ purāṇañjasaṃ pubbakehi manussehi anuyātaṃ tamanugacchiṃ.
sn12.65:7.5.eng: ‘Please sir, you should know this. While walking through a forest I saw an ancient path, an ancient route traveled by humans in the past.

sn12.65:7.6.pli: Tamanugacchanto addasaṃ purāṇaṃ nagaraṃ purāṇaṃ rājadhāniṃ pubbakehi manussehi ajjhāvuṭṭhaṃ ārāmasampannaṃ vanasampannaṃ pokkharaṇīsampannaṃ uddhāpavantaṃ ramaṇīyaṃ.
sn12.65:7.6.eng: Following it along I saw an ancient city, an ancient capital, inhabited by humans in the past. It was lovely, complete with parks, groves, lotus ponds, and embankments.

sn12.65:7.7.eng: Sir, you should rebuild that city!’

sn12.65:7.8.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, rājā vā rājamahāmatto vā taṃ nagaraṃ māpeyya.
sn12.65:7.8.eng: Then that king or their chief minister would have that city rebuilt.

sn12.65:7.9.pli: Tadassa nagaraṃ aparena samayena iddhañceva phītañca bāhujaññaṃ ākiṇṇamanussaṃ vuddhivepullappattaṃ.
sn12.65:7.9.eng: And after some time that city was successful and prosperous, populous, full of people, attained to growth and expansion.

sn12.65:7.10.pli: Evameva khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, addasaṃ purāṇaṃ maggaṃ purāṇañjasaṃ pubbakehi sammāsambuddhehi anuyātaṃ.
sn12.65:7.10.eng: In the same way, I saw an ancient path, an ancient route traveled by fully awakened Buddhas in the past.

sn12.65:8.1.pli: Katamo ca so, bhikkhave, purāṇamaggo purāṇañjaso pubbakehi sammāsambuddhehi anuyāto?
sn12.65:8.1.eng: And what is that ancient path, the ancient route traveled by fully awakened Buddhas in the past?

sn12.65:8.2.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn12.65:8.3.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn12.65:8.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho so, bhikkhave, purāṇamaggo purāṇañjaso pubbakehi sammāsambuddhehi anuyāto, tamanugacchiṃ;
sn12.65:8.4.eng: This is that ancient path, the ancient route traveled by fully awakened Buddhas in the past.

sn12.65:8.5.eng: Following it along, I directly knew old age and death,

sn12.65:8.8.eng: and the practice that leads to their cessation.

sn12.65:8.10.eng: Following it along, I directly knew rebirth …

sn12.65:8.20.eng: Following it along, I directly knew choices,

sn12.65:8.23.eng: and the practice that leads to their cessation.

sn12.65:8.24.pli: Tadabhiññāya ācikkhiṃ bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ upāsakānaṃ upāsikānaṃ.
sn12.65:8.24.eng: Having directly known this, I told the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.

sn12.65:8.25.pli: Tayidaṃ, bhikkhave, brahmacariyaṃ iddhañceva phītañca vitthārikaṃ bāhujaññaṃ puthubhūtaṃ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitan”ti.
sn12.65:8.25.eng: And that’s how this spiritual life has become successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.”

sn12.66:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kurūsu viharati kammāsadhammaṃ nāma kurūnaṃ nigamo.
sn12.66:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma.

sn12.66:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn12.66:1.7.comm: Sammasa only appears in one other case in early Pali, at Thag 1.23:1.3. The root is mas (“to rub”), suggesting the idea of examining with the fingers or “to probe”.

sn12.66:1.8.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn12.66:1.8.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha,

sn12.66:1.10.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, sammasasi antaraṃ sammasan”ti?
sn12.66:1.10.eng: “But mendicant, how do you probe within?”

sn12.66:1.12.pli: Yathā so bhikkhu byākāsi na so bhikkhu bhagavato cittaṃ ārādhesi.
sn12.66:1.12.eng: but the Buddha was not happy with the answer.

sn12.66:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn12.66:2.1.eng: When he had spoken, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,

sn12.66:2.2.eng: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!

sn12.66:2.3.pli: yaṃ bhagavā antaraṃ sammasaṃ bhāseyya. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
sn12.66:2.3.eng: Let the Buddha speak of probing within. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

sn12.66:2.4.eng: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn12.66:2.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn12.66:3.1.pli: “Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammasamāno sammasati antaraṃ sammasaṃ:

sn12.66:3.2.pli: ‘yaṃ kho idaṃ anekavidhaṃ nānappakārakaṃ dukkhaṃ loke uppajjati jarāmaraṇaṃ.
sn12.66:3.2.eng: ‘The suffering that arises in the world starting with old age and death takes many and diverse forms.

sn12.66:3.3.pli: Idaṃ kho dukkhaṃ kiṃnidānaṃ kiṃsamudayaṃ kiṃjātikaṃ kiṃpabhavaṃ, kismiṃ sati jarāmaraṇaṃ hoti, kismiṃ asati jarāmaraṇaṃ na hotī’ti?
sn12.66:3.3.eng: But what is the source of this suffering? When what exists do old age and death come to be? And when what does not exist do old age and death not come to be?’

sn12.66:3.5.pli: ‘yaṃ kho idaṃ anekavidhaṃ nānappakārakaṃ dukkhaṃ loke uppajjati jarāmaraṇaṃ.
sn12.66:3.5.eng: ‘The suffering that arises in the world starting with old age and death takes many and diverse forms.

sn12.66:3.6.pli: Idaṃ kho dukkhaṃ upadhinidānaṃ upadhisamudayaṃ upadhijātikaṃ upadhipabhavaṃ, upadhismiṃ sati jarāmaraṇaṃ hoti, upadhismiṃ asati jarāmaraṇaṃ na hotī’ti.
sn12.66:3.6.eng: The source of this suffering is attachment. When attachments exist old age and death come to be. And when attachments do not exist old age and death don’t come to be.’
sn12.66:3.6.comm: “Attachment” is upadhi, which is both the things of the world to which we cling, and the inner clinging (see Snp 1.2, MN 105:28.2.). The Jains defined upadhi similarly (Tattvārthasūtra 9.26). The dominant meaning in Sanskrit is “fraud”, which perhaps informs the Buddhist sense: the things we attach to give a false sense of security. Here it plays the role of “grasping” (upādāna).

sn12.66:3.7.pli: So jarāmaraṇañca pajānāti jarāmaraṇasamudayañca pajānāti jarāmaraṇanirodhañca pajānāti yā ca jarāmaraṇanirodhasāruppagāminī paṭipadā tañca pajānāti.
sn12.66:3.7.eng: They understand old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the fitting practice for their cessation.

sn12.66:3.8.eng: And they practice in line with that path.

sn12.66:3.9.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso sammā dukkhakkhayāya paṭipanno jarāmaraṇanirodhāya.
sn12.66:3.9.eng: This is called a mendicant who is practicing for the complete ending of suffering, for the cessation of old age and death.

sn12.66:4.2.pli: ‘upadhi panāyaṃ kiṃnidāno kiṃsamudayo kiṃjātiko kiṃpabhavo, kismiṃ sati upadhi hoti, kismiṃ asati upadhi na hotī’ti?
sn12.66:4.2.eng: ‘But what is the source of this attachment? When what exists does attachment come to be? And when what does not exist does attachment not come to be?’

sn12.66:4.4.pli: ‘upadhi taṇhānidāno taṇhāsamudayo taṇhājātiko taṇhāpabhavo, taṇhāya sati upadhi hoti, taṇhāya asati upadhi na hotī’ti.
sn12.66:4.4.eng: ‘The source of this attachment is craving. When craving exists attachments come to be. And when craving doesn’t exist attachments don’t come to be.’

sn12.66:4.5.pli: So upadhiñca pajānāti upadhisamudayañca pajānāti upadhinirodhañca pajānāti yā ca upadhinirodhasāruppagāminī paṭipadā tañca pajānāti.
sn12.66:4.5.eng: They understand attachments, their origin, their cessation, and the fitting practice for their cessation.

sn12.66:4.6.eng: And they practice in line with that path.

sn12.66:4.7.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso sammā dukkhakkhayāya paṭipanno upadhinirodhāya.
sn12.66:4.7.eng: This is called a mendicant who is practicing for the complete ending of suffering, for the cessation of attachments.

sn12.66:5.2.pli: ‘taṇhā panāyaṃ kattha uppajjamānā uppajjati, kattha nivisamānā nivisatī’ti?
sn12.66:5.2.eng: ‘But where does that craving arise and where does it settle?’

sn12.66:5.4.pli: yaṃ kho loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
sn12.66:5.4.eng: ‘That craving arises and settles on whatever in the world seems nice and pleasant.

sn12.66:5.5.eng: And what in the world seems nice and pleasant?

sn12.66:5.6.pli: Cakkhuṃ loke piyarūpaṃ, sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
sn12.66:5.6.eng: The eye in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.

sn12.66:5.11.pli: mano loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
sn12.66:5.11.eng: mind in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.’

sn12.66:6.1.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, atītamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ taṃ niccato addakkhuṃ sukhato addakkhuṃ attato addakkhuṃ ārogyato addakkhuṃ khemato addakkhuṃ.
sn12.66:6.1.eng: There were ascetics and brahmins of the past who saw the things that seem nice and pleasant in the world as permanent, as pleasurable, as self, as healthy, and as safe.

sn12.66:6.3.pli: Ye taṇhaṃ vaḍḍhesuṃ te upadhiṃ vaḍḍhesuṃ.
sn12.66:6.3.eng: As their craving grew, their attachments grew.

sn12.66:6.4.pli: Ye upadhiṃ vaḍḍhesuṃ te dukkhaṃ vaḍḍhesuṃ.
sn12.66:6.4.eng: As their attachments grew, their suffering grew.

sn12.66:6.5.pli: Ye dukkhaṃ vaḍḍhesuṃ te na parimucciṃsu jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, ‘na parimucciṃsu dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn12.66:6.5.eng: And as their suffering grew, they were not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They were not freed from suffering, I say.

sn12.66:7.1.pli: Yepi hi keci, bhikkhave, anāgatamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ taṃ niccato dakkhissanti sukhato dakkhissanti attato dakkhissanti ārogyato dakkhissanti khemato dakkhissanti.
sn12.66:7.1.eng: There will be ascetics and brahmins in the future who will see the things that seem nice and pleasant in the world as permanent, as pleasurable, as self, as healthy, and as safe.

sn12.66:7.3.pli: Ye taṇhaṃ vaḍḍhissanti te upadhiṃ vaḍḍhissanti.
sn12.66:7.3.eng: As their craving grows, their attachments will grow.

sn12.66:7.4.pli: Ye upadhiṃ vaḍḍhissanti te dukkhaṃ vaḍḍhissanti.
sn12.66:7.4.eng: As their attachments grow, their suffering will grow.

sn12.66:7.5.pli: Ye dukkhaṃ vaḍḍhissanti te na parimuccissanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, ‘na parimuccissanti dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn12.66:7.5.eng: And as their suffering grows, they will not be freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They will not be freed from suffering, I say.

sn12.66:8.1.pli: Yepi hi keci, bhikkhave, etarahi samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ taṃ niccato passanti sukhato passanti attato passanti ārogyato passanti khemato passanti.
sn12.66:8.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins in the present who see the things that seem nice and pleasant in the world as permanent, as pleasurable, as self, as healthy, and as safe.

sn12.66:8.3.pli: Ye taṇhaṃ vaḍḍhenti te upadhiṃ vaḍḍhenti.
sn12.66:8.3.eng: As their craving grows, their attachments grow.

sn12.66:8.4.pli: Ye upadhiṃ vaḍḍhenti te dukkhaṃ vaḍḍhenti.
sn12.66:8.4.eng: As their attachments grow, their suffering grows.

sn12.66:8.5.pli: Ye dukkhaṃ vaḍḍhenti te na parimuccanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, ‘na parimuccanti dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn12.66:8.5.eng: And as their suffering grows, they are not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They are not freed from suffering, I say.

sn12.66:9.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, āpānīyakaṃso vaṇṇasampanno gandhasampanno rasasampanno.
sn12.66:9.1.eng: Suppose there was a bronze goblet of beverage that had a nice color, aroma, and flavor.

sn12.66:9.2.eng: But it was mixed with poison.

sn12.66:9.3.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito.
sn12.66:9.3.eng: Then along comes a man struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched.

sn12.66:9.5.pli: ‘ayaṃ te, ambho purisa, āpānīyakaṃso vaṇṇasampanno gandhasampanno rasasampanno;
sn12.66:9.5.eng: ‘Here, worthy man, this bronze goblet of beverage has a nice color, aroma, and flavor.

sn12.66:9.8.pli: Pivato hi kho taṃ chādessati vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana tatonidānaṃ maraṇaṃ vā nigacchasi maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhan’ti.
sn12.66:9.8.eng: If you drink it, the color, aroma, and flavor will be appetizing, but it will result in death or deadly pain.’

sn12.66:9.9.pli: So taṃ āpānīyakaṃsaṃ sahasā appaṭisaṅkhā piveyya, nappaṭinissajjeyya.
sn12.66:9.9.eng: He wouldn’t put that beverage down. Hastily, without reflection, he’d drink it,

sn12.66:9.10.pli: So tatonidānaṃ maraṇaṃ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhaṃ.
sn12.66:9.10.eng: resulting in death or deadly pain.

sn12.66:9.11.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye hi keci atītamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ …pe…
sn12.66:9.11.eng: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins of the past …

sn12.66:9.13.pli: etarahi samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ taṃ niccato passanti sukhato passanti attato passanti ārogyato passanti khemato passanti, te taṇhaṃ vaḍḍhenti.
sn12.66:9.13.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins in the present who see the things that seem nice and pleasant in the world as permanent, as pleasurable, as self, as healthy, and as safe. Their craving grows.

sn12.66:9.14.pli: Ye taṇhaṃ vaḍḍhenti te upadhiṃ vaḍḍhenti.
sn12.66:9.14.eng: As their craving grows, their attachments grow.

sn12.66:9.15.pli: Ye upadhiṃ vaḍḍhenti te dukkhaṃ vaḍḍhenti.
sn12.66:9.15.eng: As their attachments grow, their suffering grows.

sn12.66:9.16.pli: Ye dukkhaṃ vaḍḍhenti te na parimuccanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, ‘na parimuccanti dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn12.66:9.16.eng: And as their suffering grows, they are not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They are not freed from suffering, I say.

sn12.66:10.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, atītamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ taṃ aniccato addakkhuṃ dukkhato addakkhuṃ anattato addakkhuṃ rogato addakkhuṃ bhayato addakkhuṃ,
sn12.66:10.1.eng: There were ascetics and brahmins of the past who saw the things that seem nice and pleasant in the world as impermanent, as suffering, as not-self, as diseased, and as dangerous.

sn12.66:10.3.pli: Ye taṇhaṃ pajahiṃsu te upadhiṃ pajahiṃsu.
sn12.66:10.3.eng: Giving up craving, they gave up attachments.

sn12.66:10.4.pli: Ye upadhiṃ pajahiṃsu te dukkhaṃ pajahiṃsu.
sn12.66:10.4.eng: Giving up attachments, they gave up suffering.

sn12.66:10.5.pli: Ye dukkhaṃ pajahiṃsu te parimucciṃsu jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, ‘parimucciṃsu dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn12.66:10.5.eng: Giving up suffering, they were freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They were freed from suffering, I say.

sn12.66:11.1.pli: Yepi hi keci, bhikkhave, anāgatamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ taṃ aniccato dakkhissanti dukkhato dakkhissanti anattato dakkhissanti rogato dakkhissanti bhayato dakkhissanti,
sn12.66:11.1.eng: There will be ascetics and brahmins in the future who will see the things that seem nice and pleasant in the world as impermanent, as suffering, as not-self, as diseased, and as dangerous.

sn12.66:11.4.eng: they will be freed from suffering, I say.

sn12.66:12.1.pli: Yepi hi keci, bhikkhave, etarahi samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ taṃ aniccato passanti dukkhato passanti anattato passanti rogato passanti bhayato passanti,
sn12.66:12.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins in the present who see the things that seem nice and pleasant in the world as impermanent, as suffering, as not-self, as diseased, and as dangerous.

sn12.66:12.3.pli: Ye taṇhaṃ pajahanti te upadhiṃ pajahanti.
sn12.66:12.3.eng: Giving up craving, they give up attachments.

sn12.66:12.4.pli: Ye upadhiṃ pajahanti te dukkhaṃ pajahanti.
sn12.66:12.4.eng: Giving up attachments, they give up suffering.

sn12.66:12.5.pli: Ye dukkhaṃ pajahanti te parimuccanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, ‘parimuccanti dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn12.66:12.5.eng: Giving up suffering, they are freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They are freed from suffering, I say.

sn12.66:13.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, āpānīyakaṃso vaṇṇasampanno gandhasampanno rasasampanno.
sn12.66:13.1.eng: Suppose there was a bronze goblet of beverage that had a nice color, aroma, and flavor.

sn12.66:13.2.eng: But it was mixed with poison.

sn12.66:13.3.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito.
sn12.66:13.3.eng: Then along comes a man struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched.

sn12.66:13.5.pli: ‘ayaṃ te, ambho purisa, āpānīyakaṃso vaṇṇasampanno gandhasampanno rasasampanno
sn12.66:13.5.eng: ‘Here, worthy man, this bronze goblet of beverage has a nice color, aroma, and flavor.

sn12.66:13.8.pli: Pivato hi kho taṃ chādessati vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi; pivitvā ca pana tatonidānaṃ maraṇaṃ vā nigacchasi maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhan’ti.
sn12.66:13.8.eng: If you drink it, its nice color, aroma, and flavor will refresh you. But drinking it will result in death or deadly pain.’

sn12.66:13.9.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, tassa purisassa evamassa:

sn12.66:13.10.pli: ‘sakkā kho me ayaṃ surāpipāsitā pānīyena vā vinetuṃ dadhimaṇḍakena vā vinetuṃ bhaṭṭhaloṇikāya vā vinetuṃ loṇasovīrakena vā vinetuṃ, na tvevāhaṃ taṃ piveyyaṃ, yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.
sn12.66:13.10.eng: ‘I can allay my thirst with a fermented drink of beer, buttermilk, salt lassi, or salted infusion. But in any case, I shouldn’t drink that beverage, for it would be for my lasting harm and suffering.’
sn12.66:13.10.comm: The drinks are surā (beer), dadhimaṇḍaka (buttermilk or whey), maṭṭhaloṇikā (salted whey or sour cream, i.e. lassi), and loṇasovīraka (salted infusion of fermented barley and herbs). These correspond with drinks mentioned, along with others, in the Cāraka Saṁhita as surā, mastu (Hindi maṭṭhā), dadhimaṇḍa, and sauvīraka. These were fermented drinks used as purgatives, and some or all were also recreational liquors. | Ayaṁ surāpipāsitā pānīyena vā vinetuṁ seems corrupt, read: ayaṁ pipāsā surāpānīyena vā vinetuṁ (“to dispel this thirst by a drink of beer”). | Loṇasovīraka is allowed as medicine (Bu Pj 3:5.33.14, Kd 6:16.3.1; preparation methods are given in Suśruta Saṁhitā 1.44 and commentary to Pj 3). It probably originated in Sovīra (DN 19:36.6). Sanskrit just has sauvīraka but Cāraka Saṁhita 3.1.18 says it can be drunk with salt; salted drinks are still popular in India. It was a great favorite of the hard-partying women of Madra, who, it was said, would sooner part with husband or son than a drop of sauvīraka (Mahābhārata 8.30). | The last phrase is corrupt, read ahitāya dukkhāya following PTS and Bodhi.

sn12.66:13.11.pli: So taṃ āpānīyakaṃsaṃ paṭisaṅkhā na piveyya, paṭinissajjeyya.
sn12.66:13.11.eng: He’d put that beverage down. After appraisal, he wouldn’t drink it,

sn12.66:13.12.pli: So tatonidānaṃ na maraṇaṃ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhaṃ.
sn12.66:13.12.eng: and it wouldn’t result in death or deadly pain.

sn12.66:13.13.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye hi keci atītamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ taṃ aniccato addakkhuṃ dukkhato addakkhuṃ anattato addakkhuṃ rogato addakkhuṃ bhayato addakkhuṃ,
sn12.66:13.13.eng: In the same way, there were ascetics and brahmins of the past who saw the things that seem nice and pleasant in the world as impermanent, as suffering, as not-self, as diseased, and as dangerous.

sn12.66:13.15.pli: Ye taṇhaṃ pajahiṃsu te upadhiṃ pajahiṃsu.
sn12.66:13.15.eng: Giving up craving, they gave up attachments.

sn12.66:13.16.pli: Ye upadhiṃ pajahiṃsu te dukkhaṃ pajahiṃsu.
sn12.66:13.16.eng: Giving up attachments, they gave up suffering.

sn12.66:13.17.pli: Ye dukkhaṃ pajahiṃsu te parimucciṃsu jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, ‘parimucciṃsu dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn12.66:13.17.eng: Giving up suffering, they were freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They were freed from suffering, I say.

sn12.66:14.1.eng: There will be ascetics and brahmins in the future …

sn12.66:14.2.pli: etarahi samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ taṃ aniccato passanti dukkhato passanti anattato passanti rogato passanti bhayato passanti,
sn12.66:14.2.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins in the present who see the things that seem nice and pleasant in the world as impermanent, as suffering, as not-self, as diseased, and as dangerous.

sn12.66:14.4.pli: Ye taṇhaṃ pajahanti te upadhiṃ pajahanti.
sn12.66:14.4.eng: Giving up craving, they give up attachments.

sn12.66:14.5.pli: Ye upadhiṃ pajahanti te dukkhaṃ pajahanti.
sn12.66:14.5.eng: Giving up attachments, they give up suffering.

sn12.66:14.6.pli: Ye dukkhaṃ pajahanti te parimuccanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, ‘parimuccanti dukkhasmā’ti vadāmī”ti.
sn12.66:14.6.eng: Giving up suffering, they are freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They are freed from suffering, I say.”
